questions.text: A 21-year-old patient has experienced severe headaches and double vision for a week. His temperature is 101.5°F. His CSF culture was positive for cryptococcal antigen. What is the site of action of the drug, would be appropriate to treat this patient systemically (not intrathecally)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The classes of antifungal drugs that have activity against Cryptococcus are the polyenes (amphotericin B formulations), the azoles, and flucytosine.
  • Fluconazoleis the best-absorbed member of the azole group and the only one that readily penetrates cerebrospinal fluid. Amphotericin would work if it were delivered intrathecally.

Fluconazole:

Fluconazole is a triazole antifungal.

It inhibits fungal cytochrome P450-dependent enzyme (14-α-demethylase), disrupts ergosterol synthesis, and impairs fungal cell membrane integrity.

Pharmacokinetics

  • High oral bioavailability, even with food.
  • Highly water-soluble, well absorbed orally, and can be given IV.
  • Excellent CSF penetration, useful in fungal meningitis.
  • Minimal hepatic CYP450 inhibition, fewer drug interactions than other azoles.
  • Widely distributed in body fluids and tissues.
  • Excreted unchanged in urine (renal dose adjustment needed)

Clinical Uses

  • Cryptococcal meningitis: Drug of choice for treatment and secondary prophylaxis.
  • Candidemia: IV fluconazole is as effective as amphotericin B in ICU patients with normal neutrophil counts. Echinocandins may be preferred in neutropenic or unstable patients.
  • Mucocutaneous candidiasis: First-line agent.
  • Coccidioidomycosis: Especially effective in meningitis form → high-dose fluconazole may avoid the need for intrathecal amphotericin B.
  • Prophylaxis: Used in AIDS patients and bone marrow transplant (BMT) recipients to prevent fungal infections.

questions.text: Interactions between this drug and cell membrane components can result in the formation of pores lined by hydrophilic groups present in the drug molecule.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The polyene antifungal drugs are amphipathic molecules that can interact with ergosterol in fungal cell membranes to form artificial pores lined by hydrophilic groups. These include amphotericin B and nystatin.

Nystatin:

Nystatin is an antifungal drug belonging to the Class Polyene antifungal, which is related to Amphotericin B

Mechanism of action:

  • Nystatin is an amphipathic molecule that can interact with ergosterol in fungal cell membranes to form artificial pores lined by hydrophilic groups.
  • In these structures, the lipophilic groups on the drug molecule are arranged on the outside of the pore, and the hydrophilic regions are located on the inside.
  • The fungicidal action of the polyenes derives from this interaction, which results in leakage of intracellular constituents.

Route of Administration:

  • Not suitable for parenteral use due to systemic toxicity.
  • Used topically or orally (not systemically absorbed).
  • Nystatin is available as Creams, Ointments, Suppositories, Oral suspension, or tablets (for local GI action)

Pharmacokinetics:

  • Poorly absorbed from skin, mucous membranes, and GI trac,t therefore leading to Minimal systemic toxicity due to poor absorption.
  • Oral use may be limited by unpleasant taste.

Clinical Uses

Primarily used for local suppression of candidal infections, including:

  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis (thrush)
  • Vaginal candidiasis
  • Intertriginous candidal infections (skin folds)

Explanation of Other Options:

Caspofungin(Option A): An echinocandin; inhibits β-1,3-glucan synthase (affects cell wall, not membrane)

Flucytosine(Option B): A pyrimidine analog; gets converted to 5-FU inside fungal cells and inhibits DNA and RNA synthesis

Griseofulvin(Option C): Disrupts microtubule function; interferes with mitosis in dermatophytes

Less expensive to use than conventional amphotericin B
More effective in fungal infections because they increase tissue uptake of amphotericin B
They decrease the nephrotoxicity of amphotericin B

questions.text: Regarding the clinical use of liposomal formulations of amphotericin B, which statement is accurate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Liposomal formulations of amphotericin B result in decreased accumulation of the drug in tissues, including the kidney. As a result, nephrotoxicity is decreased.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man living in Gujarat was transferred to California for several months. On his return to India, he complains of having influenza-like symptoms with fever and a cough. He also has red, tender nodules on his shins. You suspect that these symptoms are due to coccidioidomycosis contracted during his stay in California. This patient should be treated immediately with
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient likely has primary pulmonary coccidioidomycosis, which is often self-limiting in immunocompetent individuals.
  • A travel history can be important in the diagnosis of fungal disease. If this patient has a fungal infection of the lungs, it is probably due to immitis, which is endemic in dry regions of the western US.
  • Pulmonary symptoms of coccidioidomycosis are usually self-limiting, and drug therapy is not commonly required in an otherwise healthy patient.
  • Tender red nodules on extensor surfaces constitute a good prognostic sign.
  • Erythema nodosum is a delayed hypersensitivity response to fungal antigens.
  • No organisms are present in the lesions, and it is not a sign of disseminated disease.

When no treatment is required:

  • Immunocompetent patient
  • Mild-to-moderate symptoms
  • No evidence of dissemination


When to treat coccidioidomycosis:

  • Severe or progressive pulmonary disease
  • Disseminated disease (skin, bones, CNS)
  • High-risk groups: immunocompromised, pregnant women (especially 3rd trimester), diabetics

First-line treatment in coccidioidomycosis: Fluconazole or Itraconazole

questions.text: While doing endoscopy in an HIV+ patient, the following findings can be seen in the esophagus. Which drug is least likely to be effective in the treatment if it is used by the oral route?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • White plaques in the esophagus on endoscopy strongly suggest Candida esophagitis IN HIV HIV-positive patient.
  • Griseofulvin is least effective against Candida species. It is used for dermatophytoses (e.g., tinea infections), not for yeast infections like esophageal candidiasis.

Candida esophagitis

Candida esophagitis is a fungal infection of the esophagus, most commonly caused by Candida albicans. It is the most frequent cause of infectious esophagitis, especially in immunocompromised individuals.

Risk Factors:

  • HIV/AIDS (CD4 count < 200 cells/μL)
  • Prolonged corticosteroid therapy
  • Chemotherapy
  • Hematologic malignancies
  • Transplant recipients
  • Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus
  • Prolonged antibiotic use
  • Use of inhaled corticosteroids (e.g., for asthma/COPD, if mouth rinsing is not done)

Clinical Features:

  • Odynophagia (painful swallowing) - most common symptom
  • Dysphagia (difficulty swallowing)
  • Retrosternal chest pain
  • Oral thrush (in ~75% cases)

Treatment:

First-line (if no resistance suspected):

  • Fluconazole 200 mg loading dose, then 100-200 mg/day orally for 14-21 days
  • Swish and swallow formulations of clotrimazole and nystatin have been commonly used. (Option A and D ruled out)
  • Most of the azoles are effective in esophageal candidiasis. (Option C ruled out)

choices.text: IV amphotericin B in combination with flucytosine

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with a headache, facial pain, and a black spot over the nose. He has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus, and he was admitted to the ICU for COVID-19 15 days before. His temperature is 101 F. Examination shows left periorbital swelling that is tender to palpation, mucopurulent rhinorrhea. A photomicrograph of a specimen obtained on biopsy of the left maxillary sinus is shown. What will be the next step for management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This man has a rhino-orbital-cerebral infection caused by Mucor, a pathogen that is most commonly seen in patients with diabetes.
  • Mucor species have broad, nonseptate hyphae that branch at right angles, as seen in the photomicrograph, and can cause mucormycosis.
  • Diabetes, particularly with ketoacidosis, Immunosuppression, Chronic sinusitis (> 3 months), Iron overload, or treatment with deferoxamine, is a significant risk factor that predisposes to this condition, which typically manifests as a unilateral, invasive, maxillofacial infection with headache, facial pain, nasal discharge, and fever, as seen in this patient.
  • Treatment involves surgical debridement and intravenous Amphotericin B.

Mucormycosis management:

1. Medical

  • Liposomal Amphotericin B (drug of choice)
    • Dose: 5-10 mg/kg/day IV
    • Start immediately once suspected
  • Alternatives (only if intolerant):
    • Isavuconazole
    • Posaconazole: the only azole with activity against Rhizopus, one of the agents of mucormycosis. Liver metabolism is responsible for the elimination of posaconazole, and is used for prophylaxis of fungal infections during cancer chemotherapy and in salvage therapy in invasive aspergillosis.

2. Surgical

  • Aggressive debridement of necrotic tissue is essential
  • May need orbital exenteration or craniofacial resection in severe cases

3. Control Underlying Condition

  • Strict glycemic control
  • Minimize immunosuppressive agents if possible
  • Correct acidosis

Amphotericin B

This is a Polyene macrolide antifungal obtained from Streptomyces nodosus.

Mechanism of Action:

  • Target: Fungal ergosterol in cell membranes
  • Action: Binds to ergosterol and forms pores in the membrane, which leads to leakage of intracellular ions (K+, Mg²+) and macromolecules. It is a Fungicidal

Indications

  • Broad-spectrum: Effective against:
    • Yeasts: Candida albicans, Cryptococcus neoformans
    • Dimorphic fungi: Histoplasma, Blastomyces, Coccidioides
    • Molds: Aspergillus, Mucorales
  • DOC for severe systemic mycoses
  • Cryptococcal meningitis(induction therapy, followed by azole maintenance)
  • Other uses:
    • Topical for fungal keratitis
    • Subconjunctival injections
    • Bladder irrigation in candiduria
    • Joint injections in fungal arthritis

Adverse Effects

  • A. Infusion-related(common)
    • Fever, chills, vomiting, headache, hypotension, muscle spasms
    • Prevention: slow infusion, premedicate (antipyretics, antihistamines, steroids, meperidine)
  • B. Cumulative Toxicity
    • Renal Toxicity(most serious):
      • Reversible: ↓ renal perfusion (pre-renal failure)
      • Irreversible: tubular damage → RTA, K+/Mg²+ wasting
      • Risk ↑ with >4 g cumulative dose
      • Prevention: saline loading
    • Hematologic: Normocytic anemia (↓ EPO)
    • Hepatic: Mild LFT elevations
    • Neurologic(intrathecal): seizures, chemical arachnoiditis

Explanation of Other Options:

Oral voriconazole(Option A): Not effective against mucormycosis. Primarily used for Aspergillus

Oral nystatin(Option B): Only effective for mucosal Candida infections, Not absorbed systemically

IV amphotericin B + flucytosine(Option D): Used for Cryptococcal meningitis, not mucormycosis

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy with a history of cystic fibrosis is brought to the physician for evaluation of recurrent episodes of productive cough, wheezing, and shortness of breath over the past month. Serum studies show elevated levels of IgE and eosinophilia. An HRCT of the lungs is shown below. Antibiotic therapy is initiated. One week later, the patient continues to show deterioration in lung function. What will be your next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Failure to respond to antibiotic treatment in a patient with a history of cystic fibrosis, recurrent pulmonary exacerbations, elevated IgE levels, and CT findings of central bronchiectasis should raise concern for Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).
  • Treatment is done with Oral glucocorticoids. For acute or recurrent ABPA (as seen in this patient), oral Itraconazole should be initiated, unlike for invasive aspergillosis, voriconazole is the drug of choice(Option D ruled out)

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis:

  • ABPA is a hypersensitivity reaction to Aspergillus fumigatus (a common environmental fungus), typically occurring in patients with asthma or cystic fibrosis.
  • Type I hypersensitivity (IgE-mediated) and Type III hypersensitivity (immune complex-mediated)
  • Leads to bronchial inflammation, mucoid impaction, and bronchiectasis
  • Fungus colonizes bronchial mucus, but does not invade tissue

Treatment:

  • First line: Oral corticosteroids (e.g., prednisolone)- tapered over months
  • Adjunct: Itraconazole- reduces fungal burden and steroid dose
  • Refractory cases: Biologics (e.g., omalizumab, mepolizumab)
  • Asthma control: Inhaled bronchodilators, ICS if needed

Itraconazole:

Available in both oral and intravenous forms

Mechanisms of Action:

The antifungal activity of azole drugs results from the reduction of ergosterol synthesis by inhibition of fungal cytochrome P450 enzymes

Effective Against:

  • Dimorphic fungi:
    • Histoplasma capsulatum
    • Blastomyces dermatitidis
    • Sporothrix schenckii → drug of choice
  • Dermatophytes: Commonly used in dermatophytosis and onychomycosis
  • Aspergillus sp.: Has activity, but voriconazole is preferred

Explanation of Other Options:

IV Amphotericin B(Option A): Used in invasive fungal infections (e.g., mucormycosis), not indicated in ABPA.

Itraconazole alone(Option B): Insufficient in moderate/severe or progressive ABPA.

Voriconazole(Option C): Reserved for invasive aspergillosis or voriconazole-sensitive Aspergillus infections, not first-line in ABPA.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman was admitted to the hospital with shortness of breath and a fever to 101.5��F. She has recently received AHSCT for AML and is now immunosuppressed with tacrolimus. Serum galactomannan level is elevated. She is initiated on therapy with voriconazole. Which of the following is correct regarding the therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Calcineurin inhibitors such as tacrolimus and cyclosporine are immunosuppressive agents that are used following solid organ transplantations as well as for the treatment of graft-versus-host disease in bone marrow transplant patients.
  • These drugs are primarily metabolized via the cytochrome P450 pathway and excreted into bile.
  • In this case, voriconazole inhibits the metabolism of tacrolimus, leading to increased serum concentrations of the drug.
  • It is recommended that the tacrolimus dose be decreased to one-third of the original dose when it is necessary to co-administer tacrolimus and voriconazole.
  • The clinical signs and symptoms of tacrolimus toxicity include hypertension, edema, headaches, insomnia, and tremor.
  • In addition, elevated levels of tacrolimus can lead to worsening renal function and electrolyte abnormalities, including hyperkalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypophosphatemia, and hyperglycemia.

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought in for a progressively worsening rash on his buttocks for the last week. He cries during diaper changes and is more fussy than usual. An image of the lesion is shown below. What treatment will you prescribe?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has typical signs of a diaper rash due to Candida albicans. It can be treated with a variety of topical antifungal agents such as clotrimazole.
  • Candida albicans is part of the normal skin flora, but infection can occur when there is an imbalance that allows local Candida albicans overgrowth.

Diaper candidiasis often follows antibiotic use or prolonged wetness and presents with:

  • Beefy red rash in the diaper area
  • Satellite pustules
  • Involvement of skin folds

Explanation of Other Options:

Oral fluconazole(Option A): Oral fluconazole is used for esophageal or oral candidiasis. Diaper rash is a local infection. Reserved for refractory/severe or systemic cases

Topical terbinafine(Option C): Topical terbinafine is used for Dermatophytosis (especially onychomycosis) and Tinea infections.

Topical Ciclopirox(Option D): Topical Ciclopirox is used in Tinea versicolor, Dermatophytosis, and Seborrheic dermatitis of the scalp

questions.text: A 3-year-old child with a ventriculoperitoneal shunt develops fever with chills. On examination, the right eye deviated towards the left side. Treatment with antibiotics did not improve the condition. Culture, followed by microscopy, identifies the C. Glabrata organism. What is the preferred antifungal for the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient with Candidemia with identified organism Glabrata is resistant to fluconazole and amphotericin B. Echinocandins like Caspofungin are the Preferred drug for the patient

ECHINOCANDINS:

Examples: Caspofungin, Micafungin, Anidulafungin

Pharmacokinetics:

  • Echinocandins are large cyclic peptides attached to a long-chain fatty acid.
  • They are available only in intravenous form and are highly protein-bound.
  • Caspofungin has a half-life of 9-11 hours and is eliminated via the kidneys and gastrointestinal tract. It requires dose adjustment in severe hepatic insufficiency.

Mechanism of Action:

  • Echinocandins act by inhibiting the synthesis of β(1→3)-D-glucan, an essential component of the fungal cell wall.
  • This leads to disruption of the cell wall, osmotic instability, and fungal cell death.

Spectrum of Activity:

  • Echinocandins are highly active against most Candida species (including drug-resistant glabrata) and are also active against Aspergillus.
  • They have no activity against Cryptococcus neoformans or zygomycetes (e.g., mucormycosis).

Clinical Uses

  • Mucocutaneous and invasive candidiasis, and as empiric antifungal therapy in febrile neutropenic patients.
  • Invasive aspergillosis patients who are refractory to amphotericin B.
  • Mucocutaneous candidiasis, candidemia, and for the prophylaxis of fungal infections in bone marrow transplant patients.

Adverse Effects & Drug Interactions

  • Mild gastrointestinal upset and flushing may occur infrequently.
  • Caspofungin, when combined with cyclosporine, can lead to elevated liver enzymes, so this combination should be avoided.
  • Micafungin can increase blood levels of nifedipine, sirolimus, and cyclosporine, requiring monitoring.
  • Anidulafungin has minimal drug interactions, though histamine-mediated reactions can occur during IV infusion, especially if administered rapidly.

Explanation of Other Options:

Fluconazole(Option A): Resistance to C.Glabrata, not preferred

Amphotericin B(Option B): Active but nephrotoxic and less effective in biofilm-associated infections

Flucytosine (Option D): Not used alone due to rapid resistance

questions.text: Which of the antifungal drugs causes visual disturbances?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Voriconazole causes immediate but transient visual disturbances, including blurring of vision of unknown cause in more than 30% of patients. Based on animal studies, voriconazole is a class D drug in terms of pregnancy risk.

Adverse Effects:

  • Visual disturbances (30%)
    • Blurred vision, altered color perception, and photophobia.
    • It occurs early, reversible.
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Photosensitivity & skin cancer risk (long-term use)
  • Neurotoxicity
  • QT prolongation
  • Rash, hallucinations

Explanation of Other Options:

Caspofungin(Option B): Infusion-related effects of Caspofungin include headache, gastrointestinal distress, fever, rash, and flushing (histamine release).

Posaconazole(Option C): Visual dysfunction has not been reported with Posaconazole, but the drug is an inhibitor of CYP3A4, increasing the levels of cyclosporine and tacrolimus.

Flucytosine(Option D): Prolonged high plasma levels of flucytosine cause reversible bone marrow depression, alopecia, and liver dysfunction.

Continue current antibiotics and start amphotericin B

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman with leukemia was undergoing chemotherapy. During treatment, she developed a systemic infection. There was no erythema or edema at the catheter insertion site. Empiric antibiotic therapy was started with gentamicin, nafcillin, and ticarcillin intravenously. This regimen was maintained for 72 h, during which time the patient's condition did not improve significantly. Her throat was sore, as shown below. On day 4, none of the cultures had shown any bacterial growth, but both the blood and urine cultures grew out Candida albicans. At this point, the best course of action is to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The antibiotic regimen should be stopped immediately, since the condition of the patient did not improve after 3 days of such treatment, the cultures were negative for bacteria, and the clinical picture suggested that the patient had a fungal infection.
  • This patient is immunocompromised (leukemia + chemotherapy) and has developed systemic candidiasis (Candida albicans in both blood and urine cultures), along with oropharyngeal candidiasis
  • The preferred antifungal would be amphotericin B

Candida Infections Drug of Choice by Site & Severity

Explanation of Other Options:

Continue current antibiotics and start griseofulvin(Option A): Griseofulvin is used for dermatophyte infections (like tinea), not Candida. Keeping antibiotics unnecessarily increases the risk of resistance & toxicity.

Continue current antibiotics and start amphotericin B(Option B): Amphotericin B is the correct antifungal for systemic candidiasis. Patient is likely not septic due to bacteria, so antibiotics should be stopped unless there's clear evidence of a mixed infection.

Stop current antibiotics and start itraconazole(Option C): Itraconazole is not the drug of choice for systemic candidiasis.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman comes in with discoloration of her toenails. Physical examination shows crumbling, friable nails with hyperkeratotic debris under the affected part of the nail. Treatment with which of the following is the most appropriate oral medication for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has a fungal nail infection (onychomycosis). Terbinafine is the drug of choice.

Onychomycosis:

  • These infections are seen most commonly in the elderly, and are usually caused by dermatophyte infection, typically Trichophyton rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, or Epidermophyton floccosum.
  • Some of the more superficial lesions can be removed by simply scraping the fungus off the nail.
  • Systemic fungal therapy of months' duration (because nails grow so slowly) may be required for deeper nail lesions.
  • Although oral imidazole is used in general for nail infections, terbinafine is the drug of choice for toenail infections because toenails are difficult to penetrate and extremely slow to respond

Terbinafine:

Terbinafine belongs to the synthetic allylamine antifungal drugs

Mechanism of Action:

  • Fungicidal
  • Inhibits squalene epoxidase, an essential enzyme in ergosterol synthesis.
  • This causes a decrease in Ergosterol (disrupts fungal cell membrane) and Squalene accumulation, which is toxic to fungal cells

Clinical Uses:

  • Highly effective against dermatophytes, especially:
    • Tinea unguium (onychomycosis)
    • Tinea corporis/cruris/pedis
  • Terbinafine is available in both oral and topical formulations.
  • The oral formulation is indicated for the treatment of onychomycosis of the fingernails and toenails. The topical formulation is indicated for the treatment of tinea pedis, corporis, and cruris.

Adverse Effects:

  • Usually well-tolerated
  • Mild: GI upset, headache
  • Rare but serious: Hepatotoxicity (monitor liver function)
  • Minimal drug interactions (no P450 interference)

Explanation of Other Options:

Clotrimazole(Option A): Topical agent; ineffective in nail infections due to poor nail penetration.

Flucytosine(Option B): Antimetabolite used in systemic Candida/Cryptococcus infections, not dermatophytes

Nystatin(Option C): Effective against Candida (e.g., oral thrush), not active against dermatophytes.
